Long story short: The game is good fun and stomping around in big robots never gets old.

But the only reason I will give a good rating or a recommendation for this game is due to the following reasons:
1: Base game + older DLC's are dirt cheap during sales.
2: Modding support.

Do not get the game when its not on sale.
Do not play the game if you can not mod it. (Workshop support is enabled, so modding is easy, but if for any reason...)
Simply said: The base game without mods is simply wayyy too barebones to even be considered a proper Mechwarrior title. PGI (developer/publisher) poured a lot of love in to the game, i will admit to that. The attention to lore, timeline events and more is simply astounding. The way they tried to balance the game around all of that is also proper. But therein also lies the kicker. It feels like they tried to balance out the game too much and neglected a ton of stuff that would make the game feel more like a 'game' and not an empty slog of "go here, blow this up, get out, buy/maintain mechs".

Mods will put everything in to the game that should have been in there from the beginning and will make it so much better while also making sure you're not wasting time on the stuff that becomes a chore and doing stuff that is simply fun (it is a 'singleplayer/coöp game after all, not a sweaty online PvP fest).

And its weird. They have created Mechwarrior Online, one of the deepest and most customizable PvP games out there in terms of Mech battles, with tons of options to min-max mechs at your own desire. But then didnt do the same for this game? Was this for balance? Was this to accomodate to some sort of self-sustained lore reason? I dont know. It feels weird that they left this game so minimal and you need to turn towards modding to 'fix' the stuff that PGI simply didnt include.

In any case, if you want my mod list to enhance vanilla version with just the right things:
- HeatWarn XL 2.0
- Mech Delivery (not necessary if you want to keep things difficult, but space Amazon can be handy if you soft-lock yourself or if you want to make the entire game too easy for yourself)
- Serious Heat Sink Fix
- QOL Upgrades - Thermals and Headlights (why this isnt in the base game still baffles me to this day)
- Star Map Tips enhanced (Not necessary if you want to keep every star visit a 'mystery', But for all the people out there who dont want to waste a lot of time, this will save you time and will make the game slightly easier to reduce punishment of looking around for stuff)
- Enable Infantry (created by PGI themselves, because putting this in the game base would have jumped their age rating)
- Glassbreak
- Cockpit Glass
- Sounds of War - An ode to battletech (For all past Mechwarrior game fans)

If you want to go ALL OUT with modding and make the game the best version you can make it:
- YAML and All YAML accessories. It's really insane how this overhauls the game to great lengths.

Conditional recommend- only buy on sale. 

For a vet of Mechwarrior games (in my case, 2mercs and 4mercs) This game feels wrong. Mechs are far too fast, too 'floaty', and time to kill everything is way, way too short. There's no feeling of it being any sort of slugging match, instead it feels like a twitch shooter with some battlemech skin on it. Missions are repetitive and missions exist where you cannot clear a map- hostiles just endlessly spawn in. Most planets won't have too many contracts there, and you're encouraged to leave warzones to repair and refit, with massive time and cost penalties to repair and refit in them. The problem is that warzones are the only place to actually  get any sort of contract beyond arena missions. 

There's excellent variety in both mechs and weapons, though weapons, in particular, are a little odd, especially if you're used to tabletop rules. Lots of variation inside weapon classes- Burst fire autocannons that do more damage over a longer time, short burst lasers that don't require you to hold a beam on a moving target, stream LRMs vs. normal LRMs.... and so on. Generally this isn't too bad, though it does get a little bewildering for someone used to an AC/10 being an AC/10 without any other considerations. There's also perks and improvements that can be applied to mechs, which are sort of like design quirks, but ones you assign- so more like perks to an RPG character. 

That all said, there's a healthy mod community, with several mods looking to redress the balance and feel issues. It's because of that mod community that I think this game is worth picking up on sale- otherwise, it would be a hard pass.

MechWarrior 5: Mercenaries delivers a visceral, deeply satisfying cockpit experience that successfully captures the colossal scale and slow-motion destruction of BattleTech combat. Piloting these metallic behemoths—from the zippy flanker to the slow, indestructible Atlas—is where the game truly shines. However, the accompanying mercenary management layer feels slightly thin, and the reliance on numerous, often pricey, DLCs to deliver a complete experience ultimately weighs down the final score. It’s a great 'Mech sim trapped within a merely acceptable strategy game.

The 'Mech Experience: Weight and Power
Piranha Games absolutely nailed the feeling of piloting a BattleMech. The sense of weight and momentum is palpable, creating a genuinely distinct feel between chassis classes. Jumping into a light Raven feels like piloting a nimble "hotrod," while the heavy-hitting Centurion strikes a satisfying balance as a "medium tank." Cruising toward the enemy at 45 km/h in an Atlas lives up to the fantasy of being an "indestructible" force of nature. The visual fidelity is superb, featuring gorgeous graphics, excellent 'Mech models, and satisfying destruction physics that make walking through entire city blocks feel truly amazing. This power is complemented by an equally impressive soundscape; the weapon feedback and effects are nothing short of amazing.

Mercenary Life and Progression
The strategic layer of running your mercenary company is acceptable but misses opportunities for deeper engagement. While the core loop of contracts, travel, and upgrading is functional, it feels "dumbed down" compared to the deep customization expected from the BattleTech tabletop heritage. For instance, the simple maintenance costs are a minor gripe; the game doesn't even charge for replacing armor or ammo—elements standard to the lore and expected after every mission.

The campaign and story are acceptable, serving as a solid framework for the mission-to-mission combat. However, the immersion is sometimes broken by underwhelming cutscenes that would have benefited greatly from higher production value or even live-action video reminiscent of older titles.

The Biggest Flaw: Pathfinding and Polish
The most significant drag on the experience is the erratic allied AI. The pathfinding for your lance-mates is often god-awful, frequently requiring player intervention and occasionally compromising mission success. Fixing this solitary issue would drastically improve the flow of combat and elevate the game to a 9/10 experience.

Content and Longevity (The DLC Question)
The game is supported by a large volume of DLC. While the content itself is solid and supporting the developers is admirable, much of it feels overpriced. Locking features like melee weapons out of the base game was a questionable move that feels like an egregious cash-grab, forcing players to purchase expansions for core gameplay features. The overall longevity is decent, driven by the procedural mission generation and the ever-present pull of 'Mech collection.

Final Tally
MechWarrior 5: Mercenaries is a game of magnificent highs and middling lows. It succeeds wildly in making you feel like a powerful 'Mech pilot, but it struggles to match that fidelity in its strategic and technical execution. It’s a lot of fun, earning a firm 7.5/10, and is a must-play for fans of the franchise, provided they are willing to navigate its technical rough edges and investment in its many add-ons.

I got a lot of great moments out of this game, but also a massive amount of frustration. The feel of the mechs, the graphics, and the sound are all great, but the AI is so atrociously bad that it undermines all my enjoyment.

For example, put a human player in an LRM mech with small lasers and they will keep their distance and save the lasers for when enemies get too close. The AI in a similar situation might approach the enemy so they can use their small lasers, and in doing so will be be too close to use the missiles that provide most of their damage. Friendly AI also frequently gets stuck on terrain. The order options for friendly AI are also too simple to work around these issues. For example, you can tell an AI to stay put to keep them at roughly the right range, but you can't tell them to stay put [i] and [/i] prioritize a target. As soon as you tell them to prioritize, they will move as they please.

Meanwhile enemy AI is almost as bad. They're very clearly programmed to prioritize the mech dealing the most damage. That's fine in theory, but in practice it means that an entire group of enemies will target the player and ignore other mechs, because the friendly AI is not competent enough to do comparable damage as the player. This also causes issues in arena matches, where getting involved in the match early on will give the player a high damage output, and the other mechs will start ignoring each other completely and attack the player en masse instead.

Some of these AI issues would be forgivable if you could just ignore friendly AI, but the nature of the damage system means the missions are not really balanced for a player to complete them alone. I like that mid-mission repairs are rare, but it means if you attempt on your own, even weak enemies will chip down your health bit by bit.

With better AI this would be an easy 10/10, but as is it's more like a 5/10.

PGI simply doesn’t understand what makes mech games special and what fans actually enjoy. MW5 shows that very clearly once again. In essence, MW5 is just the offline version of MechWarrior Online - but heavily neutered. For example, you can’t choose which reactor (engine) to use, what armor to equip, or whether your mech has an AMS system.
Why? Nobody knows. Basically: just because.

Enemies don’t just exist in the world, they “spawn.” That means anything related to long-range combat - sniper weapons / long-range missiles; is basically pointless, since PGI decides when you can see an enemy and when you can’t. And to make it “more exciting,” they decided in their infinite wisdom that enemies should spawn practically in your lap. This means a brawler is always mandatory, especially since most mission triggers only activate when the player himself, not his AI teammates, walks into them.

The generic, non-story missions are always just quick runs across the map to blow something up, while the AI is so mind-numbingly dumb that it quickly kills any motivation. Because the AI - whether brawler or missile boat - only knows one tactic: Always rush straight into your lance. That instantly kills any immersion.
This is supposed to be a military simulation, where not only am I fighting for my life, but the enemy should also value theirs. Instead, two light mechs will happily charge straight into a lance of four 100-ton Mech´s - basically throwing their lives away.

Overall, there’s zero strategy, zero tactics. Just shoot, shoot, shoot. If there weren’t tonnage limits, there’d be no reason for anything other than Assault class mechs to exist. There are no drawbacks to running an Assault. Things like “scouting the area” or “let’s take the high ground and attack from there” or anything resembling military procedure simply don’t exist. Just run and blast, run and blast - always at brawler range. The only time you play long range is before the enemy manages to rush into your formation.
I’ve seen hobby projects by people who can’t even code properly with smarter AI than this. PGI really thought: “Eh, the idiots will buy anything. As long as it’s got mechs.” Why bother putting in effort?

The whole game feels like an “easy cash grab.” They already had a solid foundation with MechWarrior Online. All they did was strip out PvP and slap on a singleplayer mode - and did that terribly. The missions are brain-dead (run and blast), there’s no lore, no detailed descriptions of mechs, houses, the world, or anything else that could immerse players.
Instead, they cut costs and corners everywhere. The result is basically an arcade game you could have found in any 90s game hall. It neither satisfies the BattleTech community with depth, nor attracts newcomers with lore. It’s just: run and blast. Everything around that is meant to distract from it - but fails.

In short: a game stuffed with artificial restrictions, offering nothing but “run and blast” on tiny maps, with the dumbest AI I’ve seen in 30 years of gaming, zero immersion because the game actively works against it, and a home base that serves no purpose at all.

On top of that, you’ve got technical issues like third-rate voice acting, a German localization that’s dramatically bad, with many sentences that make no sense, no ability to look around your cockpit, no ability to eject from it and AI-Lancemates that only have one Job: Stay in your way or run straigt in your line of fire.
That just rounds the whole thing off.

Everything in this game has been carefully and deliberately crafted so that the average casual player, who only plays about 30 minutes a day, never experiences any frustration from anything that isn’t just running and blastig.

[h1] Review for Single Player only[/h1]

- Biggest flaw of this game are the eponymous "mechwarriors". They don't feel like characters. No personality. No agency. No reactivity or participation in the story. Just some modifiers you apply to your mechs.
- The gameplay does not feel tactical. Lot of long tedious walks from point A to B, then some chaotic clickfest combat. No proper tactical planning or commanding of lance mates. Stealth is horrendous.
- The content focuses on quantity over quality. There are massive numbers of mechs, variants, systems, weapons - but they do not feel substantially different. It feels like 4 hours of content stretched out into 40. Piloting one mech from another does not feel different.
- Lot of mechanics like cantina, arena etc are just plain weird and nonsensical. 
- Coming from HBS' BattleTech, the customization of mechs does not seem as fulfilling, deep and layered.
- The game is a complete eyesore. The UI is horrendous both in terms of functionality and style. The environments are ugly. Visuals get in the way of enjoyment.
- The story and characters (such as they are) are entirely unengaging and uninteresting, including the drab main character, the ops officer Ryana with her awful accent, and engineer who seems perpetually high. Feels like a single player campaign tacked on to a multiplayer game.
- We have this huge ship interior which is technically explorable in third person mode (space legs), but there is nothing to do there except go up and down the stairs between meeting with the two officers. Could have had other staff officers to interact with. Other actions to perform like meeting with your mechwarriors. Or simply being able to climb up into the mechs would have been something worth while. Wasted opportunity.
- Despite the massive far future space opera setting, the technology present in the gameworld seems very backward in an implausible inauthentic kind of way. You don't even have technical capabilities available to 1960s aircrafts or naval ships. At some point "lore" became an excuse for lazy and unimaginative game design.

I understand some of my concerns (visuals, story, characters, tactics) have been improved greatly in the subsequent Clans game. But that has come with the sacrifice of the sandbox gameworld. Those two sides of gameplay should not be mutually exclusive. 5 steps forward and 5 steps back.

I hope they can released a MechWarrior 5.5, which combines Clans story and character driven gameplay into the sandbox format (e.g. Freelancer, the new Jagged Alliance, Gears Tactics etc). I will happily pay full price again and leave a positive review.

PGI simply doesn’t understand what makes mech games special and what fans actually enjoy. MW5 shows that very clearly once again. In essence, MW5 is just the offline version of MechWarrior Online - but heavily neutered. For example, you can’t choose which reactor (engine) to use, what armor to equip, or whether your mech has an AMS system.
Why? Nobody knows. Basically: just because.

Enemies don’t just exist in the world, they “spawn.” That means anything related to long-range combat - sniper weapons / long-range missiles; is basically pointless, since PGI decides when you can see an enemy and when you can’t. And to make it “more exciting,” they decided in their infinite wisdom that enemies should spawn practically in your lap. This means a brawler is always mandatory, especially since most mission triggers only activate when the player himself, not his AI teammates, walks into them.

The generic, non-story missions are always just quick runs across the map to blow something up, while the AI is so mind-numbingly dumb that it quickly kills any motivation. Because the AI - whether brawler or missile boat - only knows one tactic: Always rush straight into your lance. That instantly kills any immersion.
This is supposed to be a military simulation, where not only am I fighting for my life, but the enemy should also value theirs. Instead, two light mechs will happily charge straight into a lance of four 100-ton Mech´s - basically throwing their lives away.

Overall, there’s zero strategy, zero tactics. Just shoot, shoot, shoot. If there weren’t tonnage limits, there’d be no reason for anything other than Assault class mechs to exist. There are no drawbacks to running an Assault. Things like “scouting the area” or “let’s take the high ground and attack from there” or anything resembling military procedure simply don’t exist. Just run and blast, run and blast - always at brawler range. The only time you play long range is before the enemy manages to rush into your formation.
I’ve seen hobby projects by people who can’t even code properly with smarter AI than this. PGI really thought: “Eh, the idiots will buy anything. As long as it’s got mechs.” Why bother putting in effort?

The whole game feels like an “easy cash grab.” They already had a solid foundation with MechWarrior Online. All they did was strip out PvP and slap on a singleplayer mode - and did that terribly. The missions are brain-dead (run and blast), there’s no lore, no detailed descriptions of mechs, houses, the world, or anything else that could immerse players.
Instead, they cut costs and corners everywhere. The result is basically an arcade game you could have found in any 90s game hall. It neither satisfies the BattleTech community with depth, nor attracts newcomers with lore. It’s just: run and blast. Everything around that is meant to distract from it - but fails.

In short: a game stuffed with artificial restrictions, offering nothing but “run and blast” on tiny maps, with the dumbest AI I’ve seen in 30 years of gaming, zero immersion because the game actively works against it, and a home base that serves no purpose at all.

On top of that, you’ve got technical issues like third-rate voice acting, a German localization that’s dramatically bad, with many sentences that make no sense, no ability to look around your cockpit, no ability to eject from it and AI-Lancemates that only have one Job: Stay in your way or run straigt in your line of fire.
That just rounds the whole thing off.

Everything in this game has been carefully and deliberately crafted so that the average casual player, who only plays about 30 minutes a day, never experiences any frustration from anything that isn’t just running and blastig.

Grab on heavy discount and some of the DLC can be avoided entirely because it's low effort slop that adds like, one mech, a bunch of awful missions and balance-destroying/pointless weapons that are rehashes of guns already in the game at best and at worst makes your game crash a bunch more according to other user complaints.

DLC positives:
- Heroes of the Inner Sphere DLC is worth it but honestly should have been base game content, take that as you wish.
- Kestrel Lancers DLC is a meaty side story campaign for you and a friend or two to chew on if you like the game's overall format and even has some meme-tier cringe dialogue to guffaw at past the halfway mark.
- If you use Yet Another Mechlab and REALLY want to punch the heck out of stuff, Call to Arms is worth it  for the melee. Banshees are turbo melee mechs that can oneshot anything in the game if tuned right. If you don't use YAML you can skip it though as melee is entirely non-viable vanilla.

DLC negatives:
- Dragon's Gambit is awful slop that adds the longbow to the loot pool. Skip.
- Solaris DLC is unforgivably bad. Skip.
- Call to Arms costs half the base game and adds a single high reward quest with no challenge. Entirely skippable due to it's poor implementation, probably should have been base game content or a HOTIS improvement to maximise it's impact.
- Kestrel Lancers DLC adds "surprise artillery" to missions which is exactly as unfun and overused as you think it is.

This game is at its most fun when with friends and even then you will most likely need mods to keep it from becoming frustrating or tedious. I feel there were some good ideas buried in here like controller support and crossplay but MW5 is the definition of "mile wide, inch deep" in terms of its content. Does the idea of you dropping into 100+ RNG-generated scenarios to do X mission in Y biome appeal to you? Do you want to play through a campaign mission set that feels barely more polished than said RNG missions where balance goes out the window soon after the tutorial is over? Does the concept of awful teammate (and enemy) AI please you, leaving you to micromanage them at every turn? Are you a diehard Battletech fan who just can't fathom the concept of playing something like the HBS Battletech game? This one might be for you, then.

PGI have a history of putting out DLCs that are half baked, requiring multiple patches after the fact to fix only half the issues introduced by them. This has the knock-on effect of breaking mods all the time, albeit often for less than a day but the message is clear: the devs don't respect the modding community that single-handedly holds this game on it's shoulders like Atlas (heh, puns). This means the game can be turned from mostly functional to unenjoyably broken at the drop of a hat. Again, I recommend HBS Battletech over this even with it's large DLC portfolio especially for solo players.

Oh yeah, this game has like 7 DLCs that total waaay more than the price of the base game, so if you want the "full experience" get ready to open that wallet of yours and shell out a fat stack of cash for the epitome of minimum viable product. The most recent DLC adds Clan mechs, something that PGI tried to hock as an entirely separate game. I guess that didn't work out so good because lo and behold Clan mechs are now shoehorn-backported into MW5 Mercs via Shadow of Kerensky DLC.

Unfortunately the stopgap measure fixes for what SoK broke on launch don't extend to my teammates constantly fighting invisible ninjas and ignoring actual targets right in front of them, a years long issue with no fix in sight. My squad will burn ammo and heat bar firing at literally nothing and turn in the wrong direction when there's 10+ targets the way I'm facing all dialled in on me. They appear to not want to engage air units or turrets at all unless they are fired upon or commanded to - seeing as the player is typically the focus of enemy attention due to their higher damage than braindead AI with no initiative this makes them doubly useless.

I get AI squadmates not proactively attacking objectives otherwise they would burn through the mission faster than the player(s) can themselves but a lot more work needs to be done before computer teammates shed their liability status, something I'd wager won't happen very soon, if ever.

Voice lines also overlap still when an enemy takes heavy damage and then dies a second or two later. Really gums up the soundscape with a dead mech pilot talking over himself.

I also noticed tanks and mech feet now sink into the ground on some slopes. Not sure what that's all about.

Would also love a setting to toggle off the weird plastic doll versions of Ryana and Forehead-- sorry, Fahad. Fahad also has tons of tiny little yellow dots all over his head. I think they're supposed to be hair, despite the fact they're the wrong colour (his facial hair is dark). [strike]At least they fixed the lighting issues causing his Kryten-itis in the latest patch.[/strike] <-- actually, it's not fixed lol

TAA forced on bug during the leopard dropship loading cutscene is still in the game six years later, I genuinely think it's never getting patched.

So yeah... hard to recommend in any way at full price but if you can grab this on a big sale and your friends already have it, you could have some fun here tagging along with them. Solo it's a really tough sell, only recommended for absolute mech-dads with money to burn and/or are happy to heavily augment this game with mods to suit their play style.

Despite how many years it's been out, there are so. many. bugs. 
From small things like literally the first textures you see in game (if you skip the tutorial) being unloaded, the holograms clipping through the table or taking on the animations of other people, to game breaking failures like friendly ai not loading and sitting at the drop point, or enemy ai just not loading in what's supposed to be a free-for-all match, meaning you end up having to 1v1 eleven other mechs that are all factory fresh.

Two assault mechs and a heavy Vs a single firestarter should not result in lost limbs.

Get it on super sale sometime, have some fun, mod the game into what it should be but PGI continues to shist the bed on this.
